fu.esi

Class IMI_ESI_Int

  • java.lang.Object
    • fu.esi.IMI_ESI_Int

  • public class IMI_ESI_Int
extends java.lang.Object
    Encapsulates an Extended Split Index that fully resides in memory (IMI, In-Memory-Index). It allows to register ints (and only ints) that reside in their bounding rect. Later they can be looked up in an hashtable manner, i.e. the caller can query for all objects that reside in a given rectangle. In principle this list could also be built up by IMI_ESI<Integer>, but for memory usage reasons, this class is more appropriate, if stored "objects" are only ints. Usally such list store geo object IDs. Other differences to IMI_ESI:
    • internally, the bounding rect is stored in intE7-format instead of double. This should make no difference in real cases, but additionally safes memory.
    • As the int content is easily to safe, this class support persistant storage

      • IMI_ESI_Int

        Parameters:

        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - read error from stream

    • Method Detail

      • writeToStream

        public void writeToStream(java.io.DataOutputStream out)
                   throws java.io.IOException
        Write the entire index structure to stream. Later, an index can be instantiated with a formerly written structure.
        Parameters:
        out - the output
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - write error to stream

      • register

        public void register(int id,
                     double min_lat,
                     double max_lat,
                     double min_lon,
                     double max_lon)
        Register an id unter a certain bounding rect. Later it can be searched by this rect.
        Parameters:
        id - the ID
        min_lat - bounding box (min latitude)
        max_lat - bounding box (min longitude)
        min_lon - bounding box (max latitude)
        max_lon - bounding box (max longitude)

      • close

        public void close()
        The list of registered id is complete and the index now can be searched. It is possible to register new objects, but then, the index has to be closed again prior to search.

      • get

        public java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> get(double min_lat,
                                                  double max_lat,
                                                  double min_lon,
                                                  double max_lon,
                                                  boolean completelyInside)
        Get all ids that reside in a given rectangle.
        Parameters:
        min_lat - query rectangle (min latitude)
        max_lat - query rectangle (min longitude)
        min_lon - query rectangle (max latitude)
        max_lon - query rectangle (max longitude)
        completelyInside, - true, if only objects with a rectangle that completely resides in the given rect. false, if also overlapping rects are collected.
        Returns:
        list of IDs
